channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: One-Third of Children in Syria Were Born During War, Unicef Report Finds
item.description: More than 300,000 in this group were born as refugees, according to a report by the United Nations Children’s Fund.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Save the Children, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two children walked through the corridors of a destroyed school last November in Eastern Ghouta, Syria. A United Nations report found that 80 percent of the country’s youth are in urgent need of humanitarian aid because of the conflict.

item.title: Sinosphere: Xi Jinping Brought Down a Notch by an Unlikely Agent: A Typo
item.description: The use of one wrong character in a Xinhua article resulted in President Xi Jinping being called “China’s last leader,” rather than “China’s highest.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping at the opening session of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere: Officials in China Call for National Standards on Halal Food
item.description: Some of China’s more than 23 million Muslims worry that businesses routinely flout Islamic law.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and ADAM WU
item.media:description: A waiter leaving the kitchen of a halal restaurant in Jiayuguan, in the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Netanyahu’s Lost Opportunities
item.description: It’s hard to understand how showing disrespect to the president of the United States serves Israel’s interests.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel last week at a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem.

item.title: Explosion in Ankara Kills at Least 34, Turkish Officials Say
item.description: The blast in Turkey’s capital, less than a month after a bombing on a military convoy in the city, was believed to have been caused by a car bomb.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A blast in the heart of Ankara killing more than 30 was the latest in a string of attacks that have destabilized the country.

item.title: South Korean Gets ‘Priceless’ Victory Over Computer in Go Match
item.description: After three straight losses, the master player Lee Se-dol rallied for his first victory against a Google program playing a board game known as the most complex ever invented.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 16 Killed in Terrorist Attack on Resort Hotels in Ivory Coast
item.description: The assault in Grand-Bassam, a popular seaside resort, pierced the national calm that has prevailed in recent years. Six terrorists were also reported dead.
item.dc:creator: LOUCOUMANE COULIBALY and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: A soldier comforted a wounded boy in Grand-Bassam, Ivory Coast, on Sunday.

item.title: Setback for Angela Merkel as Far Right Makes Gains in Germany
item.description: As three states voted, the ascendance of the Alternative for Germany pointed to strains from the chancellor’s policy of accepting refugees.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Supporters of the Christian Democratic party were dismayed by the election results in Rhineland-Palatinate on Sunday.

item.title: Quiet Support for Saudis Entangles U.S. in Yemen
item.description: The Obama administration has quietly supported the Saudi-led war in Yemen, even as American officials see a bloody quagmire there.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Fighters loyal to the Saudi-backed Yemeni government celebrated after clashes with Houthi rebels and their allies in Taiz, Yemen, on Friday.

item.title: A Killing Tests India’s Protection of an Aboriginal Culture
item.description: India has a “hands-off” policy toward hunter-gatherer tribes like the Jarawas. But what happens when a murder inquiry brings the police into an isolated society?
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A Jarawa man fashioned an arrowhead by shaping a piece of foraged metal in 2002. The Jarawas are one of India’s last intact Paleolithic tribes.

item.title: Protesters Across Brazil Call for President Dilma Rousseff’s Ouster
item.description: It was the fifth time in the past year that groups had mobilized large numbers for demonstrations in the streets against the governing leftist Workers’ Party.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Demonstrators in São Paulo, Brazil, on Sunday called for the resignation of the president amid an economic crisis and corruption scandals.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Walesa, Gorbachev and Freedom's End
item.description: In Eastern Europe, even Nobel Peace Prize winners are unsafe from the forces of illiberalism.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Gaza Journal: With Hamas Watching, Singer Creates a (Modest) Sensation
item.description: An easing of some decade-old cultural restrictions, including singing by women in front of men, has given Rawan Okasha an opportunity to start “achieving what is in my soul.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rawan Okasha before her concert in Gaza City on Thursday. With Hamas quietly easing some cultural restrictions, she is the first woman to sing in public in Gaza in nearly a decade.

item.title: Germanwings Crash Inquiry Urges Stricter Oversight of Pilots’ Mental Health
item.description: French aviation officials called for guidelines that could require doctors to report pilots whose psychological condition might imperil public safety.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Official Admits He Gave Misleading Account of Chinese Miners’ Plight
item.description: The governor of Heilongjiang Province said wages at a state-owned company were in arrears and obliquely blamed underlings for his earlier statement that they had been paid on time.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A miner for the Longmay Mining Group, in Heilongjiang Province, China. Mining conglomerates are struggling with a surplus of workers and production capacity.

item.title: Culture Gap Impedes U.S. Business Efforts for Trade With Cuba
item.description: As President Obama prepares to visit Cuba this month, the lack of trade with the former foe threatens to sap momentum from the process of building relations.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: The seafront outside the American Embassy in Havana. Cuba has made it clear that it will not alter the way it does business to suit American needs.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Where the Soldiers Are Scarier Than the Crocodiles
item.description: A catastrophe is unfolding in South Sudan, and while we may not be able to stop it, we need to try.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Two Nuer boys play with guns constructed of clay.

item.title: Opinion: How Saudi Arabia Turned Its Greatest Weapon on Itself
item.description: For decades, the kingdom used oil prices to wage economic war on its enemies. Now it’s the big casualty.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW SCOTT COOPER
item.media:description: Outside an Aramco oil field complex in Saudi Arabia in 2003.
